Among the inhabitants of the coastal region of the Gulf proper the most important elements are Persians and Persian Arabs ; the latter may be described as Arabs under Persian rule who have become denationalized by settlement, sub jection, or intermarriage; considerable numbers of them now adhere to the Shiah sect of Mohammedans, and they speak as a rule the Persian language. The settled population of the region probably consisted originally of Persians or Persian-speaking tribes. The numerous Arab settlements which have occurred seem to have come 1 Arabs in Mohammareh town are chiefly local Arabs with some descendants of Arab refugees from Bahrein.30 PERSIAN GULF partly from the mainland, from Southern Arabistan and the Ka'ab tribe, partly from the opposite side of the Gulf, from among* the Dawasir at Bahrein, and from the 'Ajmiin, Al 'Ali, and Shammar tribes in the mainland of Arabia. In some parts the two races seem to have blended, in others they are more clearly differentiated, as in the case of Arab settlements in Dashtistan, where there is an important group, of which Chakutah is the largest. There are Arab tribes in the Lingeh district and a considerable semi-Arab population in the Shibkuh district. Besides the race described above, and to a great extent mixed with them, there is in the north a strong Lur element, while in the south-east in the neighbourhood of Hormuz a Baluchi strain appears, and farther east the inhabitants of Biyaban are described as being all Baluchis. In Persian Makran there are a number of tribes mostly claiming to be descended from Arabs, who either originally settled in Makran or moved there later from Sind or Kach. Some of the inhabitants are of Indian origin, and there are many Baluchis. There are a number of Swahili negro slaves in Persian Makran. In the coastal towns the population is also very much mixed. The inhabitants of Bushire are mostly Persian, but include about 600 Jews and a few Armenians, Goanese, Baghdad Mohammedans, and some Europeans. In Bandar 'Abbas most of the population belong to a hybrid race of mixed Persian, Baluchi, Arab, and negro descent, and are known as AbbasTs. There are a number of immi grants, including Persians from Lar, from ; Avaz, and from Bastak, also Hindus, Khojahs, and Arabs. Lingeh also has a very com posite population of which the basis is Arab, chiefly immigrants from Trucial Oman and Bahrein. There is an admixture of negroes. Behind the coastal belt the population of the parts of the Persian province of Ears and Laristan which constitute the hinterland of the coastal region is extremely scanty. It is composed of tribes of mixed origin, partly settled and partly nomadic, in which Irani, Turki, and to a small extent Arab strains are present. Among the chief tribes are the Qashqai, a nomad tribe of Turki origin, a large number of whom descend to the garmsir, or warm pastures, from the mountain districts of the Persian plateau for the winter and spring months, and the Mamassani, a group of five tribes of Lur descent. The Persian language or a dialect of it is almost universallyRACE, INCLUDING LANGUAGE 31 spoken in the districts of the Persian coast, both among Persians and Arabs; a certain amount of Arabic is spoken in places. In some parts Arabic, Lur, or Baluchi modifications are introduced into the Persian dialect. In Bandar 'Abbas a dialect known as AbbasI is spoken by a section of the population. In Persian Makran the language of the country is a dialect of Baluchi called Makrani; it contains a number of Persian and Arabic words. P olitical and S ocial C onditions Arabian Coastal Region The districts which adjoin the Persian Gulf proper comprise a group of sheikhdoms and emirates under Arab rulers. Of these the Sheikh of Koweit is a mediatized ruler under British protection. Hasa is ruled by Ibn Sa'ud, Emir of Nejd, who, in June 1914, accepted the title of Vali of Nejd and Hasa from the Turks, but has remained in close relation to the British and Indian Govern ments, and during the war threw in his lot with the British. The island of Bahrein is under the personal rule of Sheikh Isa, who has been supported by the British against other claimants of his family. Qatar was occupied in 1872 by the Turks, who maintained a small garrison at Ddhah. It is now under the control of Ibn Sa'ud, Emir of Nejd. In Trucial Oman the position of the five ruling sheikhs, which include Sharjah, Dibai, Abu Dhabi, and Ras el-Kheimah, is governed by agreements with the British Government. The government of Oman is a sultanate, or absolute monarchy, the present hereditary sultanate having arisen out of an ancient elective imamate. The populations of both west and north Oman do not acknowledge his sway, and live in practical independence of him under their own chiefs, the Sultan's authority being limited to his capital and the coast. A rival imam has been set up in the interior by the principal Ibadhi sheikh. Of the Arabs of the coastal region the large majority are settled and live in towns. The Bedouin nomads who wander over the plains and hinterland, and reach even as far as Nejd or Jebel Shammar in the interior, form a proportion of the population which is small, and varies from time to time according to the location of the tribes. Among the population of the towns are many Arabs, recently nomadic, who have become settled. Among the settled32 PERSIAN GULF Arabs of this region the main distinctions are either religious or bandry, pearl political; tribal feeling is weak. In the districts adjoining the Gulf proper, where religious dis tinctions are paramount, the greater part of the population belong to the Sunni sect. Shiahs are for the most part either Baharinah or of Persian connexion. A few Wahabi Arabs from Nejd are also found among the population. The Baharinah have no tribal cohesion; the richer among them live by trade, the poorer by hus bandry, pearl-diving, and various handicrafts. In Oman political differences divide ^he population into two opposing factions known as Hinawlyah and Ghafiriyah, the result of a general civil war in the eighteenth century. The Hinawi faction consists mostly of Yamani tribes, while Ghafiri are for the most part Nizari. They live intermingled in groups and villages. The factions are equally marked among settled and among Bedouin tribes. The great majority of Hinawi tribes belong to the Ibadhi sect of Islam. Of Ghafiri tribes a considerable portion are orthodox Sunnis; a few are Wahabis of Oman. Tribal organization in Oman is loose; some tribes are scattered, others, though compact, are broken up into sections headed by sheikhs who acknowledge no common authority. In only a few cases is the tribe governed by a tawilmcih, a chief whose power extends all over its branches. This office, which is nominally elective, is in practice hereditary. Among the nomads of the Arabian coastal region tribal feeling is strong. Important tribes are : 1. The 'Ajman, of whom the greater number have their head quarters in Hasa. 2. The 'Awazim and Rashaidah, who are found for the most part in Koweit territory. Head of the Gulf The districts of Irak at the head of the Gulf formed a part, before the war, of the Turkish vilayet of Basra. The government of Southern Arabistan is administered by the Sheikh of Moham- mareh, as Governor of Mohammareh and its dependencies, nominally under the Persian Government; he is head of the Mn- haisin tribe, and exercises control over the powerful Ka'ab tribe. The Sheikh has been virtually independent, but his position was weakened when, in 1902, the control of the customs of the port wasPOLITICAL AND SOCIAL CONDITIONS 33 transferred to that of the new Belgian administration in exchange for a subsidy. Behbehan, though geographically belonging to Fars, has an administration and a government of its own. On the right bank of the Shatt el-'Arab there is very little tribal feeling, except among the Muhaisin, who look to the Sheikh of Mohammareh as their chief; power is in the hands of the land owners and village sheikhs. In Arabistan the tribal system is more highly developed; it does not rest upon a rigid basis of race, and the strength of the tribe or section is liable to be increased by addition to its numbers from without, or diminished by desertion from within; sheikhs or headmen of the tribes or sections are generally chosen from a family in which the office is hereditary. Some of the tribes are settled, others are nomadic, while a con siderable number are in a transitional stage between the two. The settled and semi-settled tribes are mainly agricultural, and the nomadic mainly pastoral, but even the latter cultivate a certain amount of grain in winter. On the right bank of the Shatt el-^Arab are Arabs belonging chiefly to the tribe of ^Idan, with a few Muhaisin from across the river. In Southern Arabistan the principal tribes are the Muhaisin and the Ka^ab: the former are politically stronger, the latter numerically. The Muhaisin have their centre at Mohammareh and are a settled tribe. The Ka'ab, whose focus is Fellahlyeh, should probably be regarded as settled. The principal nomad tribes are the Beni Turuf, Beni Saleh, and Beni Tamim. In Behbehan province a large number of the inhabitants belong to the Kuhgalu, a division of the Lur tribe; each division of the tribe has its own chief. The Persian Littoral Local districts of the Persian coast are for the most part under the government of a local hereditary chief, khan, or sheikh, who collects the land tax in his own domain on behalf of the Persian Government. Certain districts are in a very disturbed state, others remarkably orderly; the inhabitants are for the most part much more civilized than the tribesmen of the interior. Blood feuds are common, and cattle raids sometimes lead to encounters between the34 PERSIAN GULF different tribes and factions. There are no criminal courts beyond the personal administration of the governor or local khan; civil justice of a sort is dispensed, but it is extremely venal. In religion the inhabitants are almost entirely Shiah Mohammedans. Some of the Arabs are Sunnis, but a great many of them ^eem to have become Shiah. Persian Makran is nominally administered by a governor, who has his seat at Biimpur, subject to the authority of the Persian Governor-General of Kirman; in practice this official is rarely appointed, and the country is in a condition of anarchy. The country is divided into five districts, each of which is ruled by a chief who is supposed to pay tribute to the governor, but in the administration of his district is free from interference by the Persian executive. The chiefs of districts are assisted by the re ligious authorities, or mullahs, and by headmen of the villages. There is no organized system of law and order, and serious dis turbances have been common in recent years. The blood feud remains customary, and slavery prevails in most parts of the country. In religion the people are Mohammedans, most of the Sunni sect. Population Arabian Coastal Region 1. The total population, settled and nomadic, of the districts adjoining the Gulf proper is said to be in the neighbourhood of 300,000. This is made up as follows: Koweit . . 37,000 settled 13,000 nomadic Hasa . . . 100,000 „ 50,000 Qatar . . . 26,000 „ unknown Trucial Oman . 72,000 „ 8,000 „ The islands of Bahrein have about 100,000 inhabitants. The population of the district as a whole is extremely scanty, and vast tracts are either uninhabited or are inhabited only at certain times of the year by a few nomads. Chief centres of population are : (i) Certain coastal towns and ports connected with the interior by caravan routes. The great majority of the inhabitants of these towns take part in the pearl-fisheries and in the smaller industries connected with them, such as boat-building, sail-making, &c. There are also considerable sea-fisheries, in which some of the pearl-fishers take part during the winter.POPULATION 35 The numbers of inhabitants of these towns are as follows: Koweit Qatif . . . . . Bida Abu Dhabi Dibai Sharjah Manamab, on the island of Bahrein Muharraq, „ „ „ 35,000 5,000 12,000 6,000 20,000 15,000 25,000 20,000 (ii) The oases of Hasa and Qatlf. These include extensive dis tricts of considerable fertility; the inhabitants are mainly occupied in agriculture. Hasa oasis has a population of 67,000, of whom 25,000 are included in the capital Hofuf. The population of Qatlf oasis is 26,000. 2. Of the districts which adjoin the Gulf of Oman, the sultanate of Oman has about 500,000 inhabitants, of whom 30,000 are nomads, in the hinterland. Oman proper is said to have a popula tion of 34,300. Bedouins are numerous in Oman proper and on the verge of the desert generally, but their numbers cannot be estimated. The most populated districts of Oman are: (i) The coastal plain of Batinah, which has a settled population of 105,000 engaged for the most part in agriculture and the cultiva tion of dates and in the coastal fisheries. (ii) The Wadi Sema'il, a most populous valley with a settled population of 2,000 engaged largely in date cultivation. (iii) The coastal towns, of which Maskat has a population of 10,000 and Matrah has 11,000. Matrah, Sur (pop. 12,000), and Sohar (pop. 7,500) are starting-points of caravan routes to the interior. Kaburah has 8,000 inhabitants. The inhabitants of coastal towns are engaged in the fisheries and local maritime trade, and also in trade with the east coast of Africa and with India. Tom/s and Villages. —Owing to the barren and waterless nature of the region the inhabitants are found mostly in the coastal towns; villages are numerous only where there are oases and springs and cultivation is possible. There are many villages in the oases of Hasa and Qatif, in the island of Bahrein, along the Batinah coast, and in the Wadi Sema'il, and in the districts inland and in the mountains of Oman. A certain number of the inhabitants of the towns, who are not occupied in the fisheries, are engaged in minor industries, such as36 PERSIAN GULF boat-building, sail-making 1 , metal industries, and the weaving of abhas. In the larger towns, and especially in Hofuf, where contact with the outside world is maintained through Indian and other merchants, buildings and architecture are more elaborate, and a higher standard of life prevails. Village life is primitive. The inhabitants of villages are engaged almost exclusively in agriculture. Increase and Decrease. —Increase and decrease in population are due in the Arabian coastal region chiefly to local causes. In the months between May and September there is a considerable influx of population for the pearl-diving, and boats come to this coast from the Persian shore and from all parts of the Gulf. In autumn there are local movements of population for the purposes of the date harvest. The population also varies according to the movements of the Bedouin. These are engaged in the rearing of flocks of sheep and in camel breeding. During the winter and spring they wander far and wide over the plains in search of pasture. In the hot weather they come in to the wells and oases. They also visit the towns in order to make purchases and to sell live stock and ghi. Head of the Gulf The population of the districts of Turkish Irak at the head of the Gulf probably approaches 120,000; of these about 40,000 inhabit the town of Basra ; most of the remainder are found in the numerous villages, which are situated in the date-groves which line the banks of the river. These are engaged in agricul ture, principally in date culture. The population iu the hinterland is scanty. The population of Southern Arabistan is probably rather over 200,000. The town of Mohammareh has about 18,000 inhabitants, HawTzeh has 5,000, Fellahlyeh 2,000, Hindiyan about 4,000. Large parts of the country are uninhabited or only sparsely populated. The numbers of settled inhabitants and nomads are probably about equal. The former, with the exception of the comparatively small numbers who live in towns, are found in the villages, which are numerous in certain parts of the country. There are many villages on the left bank of the Shatt el-'Arab, and a certain number on the banks of the Karun in the Mohammareh district. In the Fellahlyeh district most of the(E) POPULATION 37 villages are agricultural settlements, situated on canals taken off from the JerrahT river. There are a number of villages also on the Hindiyan river. The great bulk of the nomads inhabit the districts of Ahwaz and Hawizeh; in summer and autumn they camp in the marshes, in winter and spring they roam over the desert with their flocks and herds. A proportion of the nomads migrate between the Persian and Turkish sides of the frontier. The Muhaisin, who are looked upon as a settled tribe, leave Mohammareh at certain times of the year in order to cultivate their grain lands on the Karun. The population of the town of Behbehan is said to be from 12,000 to 15,000. The number of inhabitants is probably over 300,000; this in cludes the population of coastal towns, of which Bushire has about 25,000, Lingeh about 12,000, and Bandar 'Abbas about 10,000. The population of Persian Makran is estimated at about 114,000. With the exception of the towns mentioned above, the population is scattered in numerous small villages along the sea-coast, or in the coastal plain at the foot of the mountains. The inhabitants are engaged principally in agriculture, growing wheat and barley— date cultivation is small on the Persian coast—or in seafaring occupations, pearl-diving, sea-fishing, and Ihe local carrying trade; in the harvest season all are engaged in the fields. The Persian population is mainly engaged in agriculture, the Arabs partly in agriculture and partly in maritime pursuits. There is a con siderable amount of coastal trade between the seaports of the Persian littoral; also between these ports (notably Lingeh) and the Arabian coast, and especially Bahrein and Trucial Oman. Dwellings in the villages are for the most part primitive and consist largely of huts made of date leaves plastered with mud ; in the towns buildings are more substantial and are made of stone and plaster of Paris, or sun-dried bricks and mud. mods.abstract: This volume concerns the geography of the Persian Gulf published by the Naval Staff Intelligence Department in June 1919. It is divided into two sections: 'Physical Geography', including 'Position and Frontiers', 'Surface, Coasts and Islands, River Systems', and 'Sanitary Conditions' (ff. 3-15); and 'Man', including 'Race, including Language', 'Political and Social Conditions', and 'Population' (ff. 15v-20). The title page is marked with 'For Official Use only' (f. 1).
